title.narrative: RWI of Human Rights and Humanitarian Aid (RWI) Southeast Asia 10-15
RWI of Human Rights and Humanitarian Aid (RWI) Sydost Asien 10-15

description.narrative: Regional program for capacity building in human rights with two purposes: first, to strengthen national institutions for human rights (NHR) institutional capacity to promote and protect human rights, and second, to strengthen the capacity of academic institutions in SEA to deliver high-quality educ / research in the field for MR and participate actively in the public debate on Human rigths.

Regionalt program för kapacitetsutveckling inom mänskliga rättigheter med två syften; det första att stärka nationella institutioner för MR(NHRI) institutionella kapaciteten att främja och skydda mänskliga rättigheter;och det andra att stärka kapaciteten hos akademiska institutioner i SEA att leverera högkvalitativ utb/ forsk inom området för MR samt delta aktivt i den offentliga MR debatt.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The project was evaluated in 2015, the overall conclusion being that the majority of the expected results were achieved. The project was extended to include 2016 at the request of RWI to be able to keep a minimum level of activities and not lose momentum awaiting the new Swedish Regional Strategy for regional development cooperation to be adopted before sending in a new proposal.
This assessment in this statement concludes the summary of results achieved during the years 2015 and 2016 of the RWI regional project for South East Asia.
The main focus of the RWI regional project for South East Asia was to strengthen National Human Rights Institutions (NHRIs) and Academic institutions and their capacity and knowledge about human rights.
RWI has carried out all planned activities with minor exceptions. The Embassy makes the assessment that the intention of the project has been achieved; that RWI has in contributed to increase the capacity of both academic institutions and NHRIs in terms of knowledge about human rights and human rights mechanisms, increased the regional capacity for human rights research, improved access to human rights information and developed human rights libraries and increased the exchange of experiences between academic institutions and NHRIs actors in the region. A few examples of results.
RWI supported the National Human Rights Commission in Sri Lanka in collaboration with Asia Pacific Forum of National Human Rights Institutions (APF) to build their capacity on how to conduct inquiries on alleged human rights violations.
In relation to research, the project supported the development of research skills of scholars and a number of qualitative research papers were finalized and on topics such as human rights, business and environment and presented in a regional fora. The Program produced a study on juvenile justice in ASEAN which has generated great interest especially in AICHR. RWI was also involved in an informal seminar with Asia Europe Meeting (ASEM) 2015 on human rights and trafficking in persons as well as contributing to the informal ASEM meeting 2016 in China on human rights for persons with disabilities, which gathered 120 participants of high level senior government officials and representatives from disabled people’s organizations. The meeting focused on the participation and inclusion of people with disabilities in political and cultural life, social and economic inclusion, legal status, justice and remedy, national implementation of the CRPD and international cooperation. RWI under this program, contributed to the development of an alumni platform among academic institutions in the region. A pilot blended learning course on human rights and Environment was carried out in November 2015 with great success and was repeated in 2016. The model of having blended learning courses with a mix of participants from NRHIs and Academic institutions was appreciated and increased the exchange of experiences between them. There is an increasing awareness regarding the links between environment, development and human rights and an increased demand for more knowledge about the links between international human rights law and international environmental laws. During the final years of the project, RWI has initiated the establishment of collaboration between regional actors such as OHCHR, UNDP, ICJ, AICHR, ASEAN CSR network, Stockholm Environment Institute. RWI applied for consultative status at ASEAN Intergovernmental Commission on Human Rights (AICHR) which was approved in 2017. This is considered to be an important indicator that RWI has gained credibility and trust in relation to AICHR.
RWI has strived to assure that the participation in the project supported activities has had a good gender balance of men and women. Attention to gender equality has been made in relation to the research component where the importance of gender analysis was discussed. The project has included training in CEDAW, even if no such activities were carried out in 2016. RWI is becoming more attentive to gender equality, but there is still more to be done in order to conclude that it is given full attention. In conclusion, the Embassy makes the assessment that RWI has managed well in achieving attended outcomes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
